case_vignette: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856-g (8-lb, 8-oz) newborn male. She had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 ml of blood. During the procedure, she received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below her waist and 0/5 muscle strength in her lower extremities. She feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of her great toes. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

Have you had any recent injuries or accidents?

No, I have no history of serious illness and take no medications.

I haven't mentioned anything about my family's medical history.
Have you noticed any changes in your mood or behavior?
No, I'm alert and oriented to person, place, and time.

No, I haven't had any seizures or convulsions.

I haven't mentioned any changes in my vision or hearing.

I haven't mentioned any changes in my speech or language.

I haven't said anything about changes in my coordination or balance.
Have you noticed any changes in your reflexes or muscle tone?
My deep tendon reflexes are absent in my lower extremities.
Final Diagnosis: Peroneal Neuropathy.
